words.meaning_en: fellow members of a group, often in military or political contexts

words.meaning_en: to give something and receive something in return

words.meaning_en: to accept, admit, or recognize something
words.origin_en: From Middle English, from 'knowledge' with prefix 'ac-'.

words.meaning_en: improved or made better
examples: The enhanced features of the app improved user experience.

words.meaning_en: to use something to its maximum advantage
words.origin_en: From 'leverage', which comes from 'lever' (a tool for mechanical advantage).

words.meaning_en: a thick, sweet liquid made from sugar, used in cooking or as a topping
examples: She poured syrup over the pancakes.
The doctor prescribed cough syrup for her cold.

words.meaning_en: a type of tree known for its leaves and sweet sap used to make syrup
examples: The maple tree is famous for its vibrant autumn colors.
Maple syrup is a popular topping for pancakes.

words.meaning_en: more courageous, confident, or striking
words.meaning_es: mÃ¡s audaz, mÃ¡s atrevido, mÃ¡s destacado
words.origin_en: Comparative form of 'bold', from Old English 'bald' (brave).
words.origin_es: Forma comparativa de 'bold', del inglÃ©s antiguo 'bald' (valiente).
examples: She became bolder after facing her fears.

words.meaning_en: the process of careful thought or discussion before making a decision
examples: After much deliberation, she decided to take the job.
The committee's deliberation lasted for several hours.

words.meaning_en: moving closer to something in distance, time, or situation
examples: The deadline is quickly approaching.
The car is approaching the intersection.
She is approaching the problem with a new perspective.

words.meaning_en: a spice made from the dried bark of certain tropical trees, commonly used in cooking and baking
examples: She added a pinch of cinnamon to the apple pie.

words.meaning_en: a legal document or justification for an action
words.origin_en: From Old French 'warant', of Germanic origin.
words.origin_es: Del francÃ©s antiguo 'warant', de origen germÃ¡nico.

words.meaning_en: the past tense of 'undergo', meaning to experience or endure something
words.origin_en: Past tense of 'undergo', from Old English 'undergan'.
examples: She underwent surgery last week.

He underwent a difficult training program.

words.meaning_en: from the beginning to the end of something, or across an entire area
words.meaning_es: a lo largo de, durante todo, en todo
examples: He worked hard throughout the year.

words.meaning_en: to have a deep emotional impact, to be understood, or to produce sound vibrations
examples: Her speech truly resonates with me.
The book resonates with readers of all ages.
The sound of the bell resonates through the hall.

words.meaning_en: to give support, confidence, or motivation to someone
examples: Parents should encourage their children to read.
Her words encouraged me to keep going.
The company encourages innovation and creativity.

words.meaning_en: used to contrast or introduce a different idea
examples: She is very talented. However, she lacks experience.
The weather was bad; however, we still went outside.

words.meaning_en: structures for storing goods or isolated systems within an organization
words.origin_en: From Spanish 'silo', ultimately from Greek 'siros' (pit for grain).
words.origin_es: Del espaÃ±ol 'silo', originalmente del griego 'siros' (foso para grano).

words.meaning_en: honest, open, or direct about something; also payment in advance
examples: We need the payment upfront before starting the work.
I'll be upfront, I don't think this plan will work.
She was upfront about the challenges of the project.

words.meaning_en: expresses a feeling or desire for something to happen
examples: Hopefully, it won't rain tomorrow.
Hopefully, we can solve this issue soon.
Hopefully, the next season will be better.

words.meaning_en: causing great pleasure or joy
examples: We had a delightful evening at the park.
She's a delightful person to work with.
This cake is absolutely delightful.

words.meaning_en: eager or enthusiastic; also sharp or acute
examples: She was keen to start her new job.
He has a keen eye for detail.

words.meaning_en: appealing or attractive
examples: The cake looked so tempting I had to try it.

words.meaning_en: a person captured and held against their will
examples: The hostage was released after negotiations.

words.meaning_en: relating to a person of white race
words.origin_en: From 'Caucasus', a region between Europe and Asia.
words.origin_es: De 'CÃ¡ucaso', regiÃ³n entre Europa y Asia.
examples: He is of Caucasian descent.

words.meaning_en: an unusual or eccentric person
words.origin_en: Origin uncertain, possibly from Old English 'frician' (to dance).
words.origin_es: Origen incierto, posiblemente del inglÃ©s antiguo 'frician' (bailar).
examples: He's a total freak when it comes to gaming.

words.meaning_en: small portions of something
examples: I only need a few bits of information to complete the task.

words.meaning_en: extending in one direction without curving; honest and direct; heterosexual
words.origin_en: From Old English 'streht', past participle of 'streccan' (to stretch).
words.origin_es: Del inglÃ©s antiguo 'streht', participio pasado de 'streccan' (estirar).
examples: Draw a straight line from A to B.
Go straight ahead for two blocks.
I'll give you a straight answer: I don't know.

She has straight hair.
He's been working for 10 hours straight (continuously).

words.meaning_en: the first appearance of light in the morning; the beginning of something
words.meaning_es: amanecer, alba; el comienzo de algo
words.origin_en: From Old English 'dagian' (to become day), related to 'day'.
words.origin_es: Del inglÃ©s antiguo 'dagian' (convertirse en dÃ­a), relacionado con 'day' (dÃ­a).
examples: We woke up at dawn to watch the sunrise.

Dawn is breaking over the mountains.

words.meaning_en: the edge of a sidewalk; to restrain or control something
words.origin_en: From Latin 'curvare' (to bend, curve). Originally referred to a curved restraining strap, later applied to the curved edge of a street.
words.origin_es: Del latÃ­n 'curvare' (doblar, curvar). Originalmente se referÃ­a a una correa de restricciÃ³n curva, luego aplicado al borde curvo de la calle.
examples: The car hit the curb and got a flat tire.

words.meaning_en: a rope or chain used to control a dog or other animal; to control or restrain
words.origin_en: From Old French 'laisse', meaning 'a thong, string, or lace'.

words.meaning_en: a physical fight using only fists; a brawl or scuffle
words.meaning_es: pelea a puÃ±etazos, pelea con los puÃ±os
words.origin_en: Compound word from 'fist' (closed hand) + 'fight' (combat). Used since the 1600s to describe hand-to-hand combat without weapons.

examples: The argument escalated into a fistfight.

The referee stopped the fistfight before anyone got seriously hurt.

He walked away to avoid a fistfight.

words.meaning_en: plural of fist; closed hands with fingers curled into the palm

examples: He clenched his fists in anger.

They shook their fists at the referee.
She punched the air with both fists.

words.meaning_en: used to emphasize a statement or response; in truth; truly
words.origin_en: From Middle English 'in dede', literally meaning 'in fact' or 'in action'. Combines 'in' + 'deed' (action).
words.origin_es: Del inglÃ©s medio 'in dede', literalmente 'en hecho' o 'en acciÃ³n'. Combina 'in' + 'deed' (acciÃ³n).
examples: That is indeed a good idea.

words.meaning_en: hitting your toe or foot against something hard; in testing, creating fake objects to simulate behavior
words.meaning_es: golpear el dedo del pie contra algo duro; en pruebas, crear objetos falsos para simular comportamiento
words.origin_en: From 'stub', Middle English 'stubbe', meaning a tree stump or short projecting part.
words.origin_es: De 'stub', del inglÃ©s medio 'stubbe', que significa tocÃ³n de Ã¡rbol o parte corta que sobresale.
examples: I keep stubbing my toe on the table leg.

words.meaning_en: a passage between rows of seats or shelves
words.meaning_es: pasillo entre filas de asientos o estantes
words.origin_en: From Old French 'ele' meaning 'wing' (of a church). Note: sounds exactly like 'isle' (island) but spelled differently.
words.origin_es: Del francÃ©s antiguo 'ele' que significa 'ala' (de una iglesia). Nota: suena exactamente como 'isle' (isla) pero se escribe diferente.
examples: The bride walked down the aisle.

words.meaning_en: a small piece or brief extract of something; in programming, a reusable piece of code
words.meaning_es: fragmento, pedazo pequeÃ±o; en programaciÃ³n, trozo de cÃ³digo reutilizable
words.origin_en: From 'snip' (to cut with scissors) + diminutive suffix '-et'. First recorded in the 1660s.
words.origin_es: De 'snip' (cortar con tijeras) + sufijo diminutivo '-et'. Registrado por primera vez en los 1660s.
examples: I heard a snippet of their conversation.

words.meaning_en: mixed up in a confused or disorderly way; cooked eggs stirred while frying; rushed or moved quickly
words.meaning_es: revuelto, mezclado de forma desordenada; huevos revueltos; moverse apresuradamente
words.origin_en: From 'scramble', possibly imitative or from Dutch 'schrammen' (to scratch). Used since the 1500s.
words.origin_es: De 'scramble', posiblemente imitativo o del holandÃ©s 'schrammen' (rascar). Usado desde los 1500s.
examples: I had scrambled eggs for breakfast.

The fighter jets scrambled in response to the threat.

words.meaning_en: an extended period or duration; 'long' here means extended in duration, not physical length
words.meaning_es: mucho tiempo, largo tiempo; 'long' aquÃ­ significa extendido en duraciÃ³n, no longitud fÃ­sica
words.origin_en: From Old English 'lang' meaning 'having great linear extent'. Extended metaphorically to time duration since Old English period.
words.origin_es: Del inglÃ©s antiguo 'lang' que significa 'tener gran extensiÃ³n lineal'. Extendido metafÃ³ricamente a la duraciÃ³n del tiempo desde el perÃ­odo del inglÃ©s antiguo.
examples: It's been a long time since we last met.
I haven't seen you in a long time!
That took a long time to finish.
We've been waiting for a long time.
Long time no see! (informal greeting)
It will take a long time to complete this project.
words.note: âš ï¸ IMPORTANT: 'Long' with TIME means DURATION (how much time), NOT distance. We use 'long' for time periods: 'a long time', 'how long?', 'for a long while'. We DON'T say 'a big time' or 'a large time'. Compare: 'a long road' (physical distance) vs 'a long time' (duration). Other time expressions with 'long': 'all day long', 'all night long', 'how long will it take?', 'as long as needed'.

words.meaning_en: making a deep, continuous sound; stomach making noise from hunger; early signs of discontent or unrest
words.meaning_es: hacer un sonido profundo y continuo; estÃ³mago haciendo ruido por hambre; seÃ±ales tempranas de descontento o inquietud
words.origin_en: From 'rumble', Middle English, possibly imitative of low, rolling sounds like thunder. First recorded in the 1300s.
words.origin_es: De 'rumble', inglÃ©s medio, posiblemente imitativo de sonidos bajos y rodantes como el trueno. Registrado por primera vez en los 1300s.
examples: I heard a rumbling sound in the distance.
